TypeSignature.Value: .class nested protected auto ansi beforefieldinit DataGridViewRow/DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject extends System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject

Docs.summary: Provides information about a to accessibility client applications.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Windows Forms includes built-in accessibility support that allows your application to work with accessibility client applications. Examples of accessibility client applications include screen enlarger and reviewer utilities, voice input utilities, on-screen keyboards, alternative input devices, and keyboard enhancement utilities.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject> class inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> class to provide information about a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow> to accessibility client applications. Each class that represents a visual part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> - such as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> - also contains a class that inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> to provide information about the containing class and perform actions on behalf of accessibility client applications.
There are instances when you will want to provide additional information, such as the name or description of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control, to accessibility client applications. There are two ways of providing this additional information. To provide limited accessibility information for existing controls, set the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleName%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDescription%2A> property values, which will be reported to accessibility client applications.
> [!NOTE] > You should change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDefaultActionDescription%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleRole%2A> property values only in rare situations, such as if you make a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> look like a list.
Occasionally, you might require more accessibility information or different accessibility actions to be included with your custom <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>. To customize accessibility, you can write your own class that derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject> classes and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method. For example, if you are writing a custom row header cell that implements unique custom actions, such as special hit testing within your cell, you should create a class that inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.DataGridViewRowHeaderCellAccessibleObject> class and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> exposes its data structure by using <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleRole> values to define the data table hierarchy. For more information on exposing data tables to Microsoft Active Accessibility, see "Exposing Data Tables through Microsoft Active Accessibility" in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject Navigate(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation navigationDirection) cil managed
Public Overrides Function Navigate (navigationDirection As AccessibleNavigation) As AccessibleObject

Docs.returns: An that represents an object in the specified direction.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following table describes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.Navigate%2A> method will return for each `navdir` value.
|Parameter value|Return value| |---------------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Down> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Next>|An accessible object for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow> below the current row.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Up> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Previous>|An accessible object for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow> above the current row.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.FirstChild>|An accessible object for the first <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> in the row. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell> is the first cell if <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.RowHeadersVisible%2A> is `true`.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.LastChild>|An accessible object for the last <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> in the row.| |All other <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation> values|`null`.|

.method public hidebysig virtual instance void Select(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection flags) cil managed
Public Overrides Sub Select (flags As AccessibleSelection)

Docs.summary: Modifies the selection or moves the keyboard focus of the accessible object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following table describes the action that <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.Select%2A> method will perform for each `flags` value.
|Parameter value|Action| |---------------------|------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.TakeFocus>|The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> takes focus.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.TakeSelection>|The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> in the row takes focus.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.AddSelection>|The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> is added to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.SelectedCells%2A> property.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.RemoveSelection>|The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> is removed from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.SelectedCells%2A> property.|
When you specify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.TakeSelection> value, the column of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> that currently has focus is the same as the cell that will take focus in the current <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow>. For example, if row 10, cell 3 has focus, and you specify <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.TakeSelection> for row 15, then row 15, cell 3 will have focus. The first cell in the row will take focus if no <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> has focus.

public: virtual property System::Windows::Forms::AccessibleStates State { System::Windows::Forms::AccessibleStates get(); };

Docs.value: A bitwise combination of values. The default is the bitwise combination of the and values.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.State%2A> property includes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Selected> value if the all of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> objects in the row are selected. <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.State%2A> does not indicate whether the row has scrolled out of view.

Docs.exception: The value of the property is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.Value%2A> property includes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject.Value%2A> property for each cell in the row. <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.DataGridViewRowAccessibleObject.Value%2A> returns the string "(Create New)" if the current row is a new row.
